original.title: Book V: Women, Children & Philosopher Kings
original.preview: Socrates: Such is the good and true City or State, and the good man is of the same pattern.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such is the good and true City or State, and the good man is of the same pattern; and if this is right every other is wrong.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What are the evil forms?

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Socrates was proceeding to tell the order in which the four evil forms appeared when Polemarchus, sitting nearby, began to whisper to Adeimantus. He stretched forth his hand, took hold of Adeimantus by the shoulder, and said something in his ear.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly not, we shall not let him off.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Who is it you are refusing to let off?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You. We think that you are lazy, and mean to cheat us out of a whole chapter which is a very important part of the story.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You fancy that we shall not notice your airy way of proceeding; as if it were self-evident to everybody, that in the matter of women and children 'friends have all things in common.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And was I not right, Adeimantus?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, but what is right in this particular case requires to be explained. Please tell us what sort of community you mean.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: We have been long expecting that you would tell us something about the family life of your citizens—how they will bring children into the world, and rear them when they have arrived.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: To that resolution you may regard me as saying Agreed.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: And without more ado, you may consider us all to be equally agreed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You know not what you are doing in thus assailing me! What an argument are you raising about the State!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Just as I thought that I had finished, and was only too glad that I had laid this question to sleep, you ask me to begin again at the very foundation.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: For what purpose do you conceive that we have come here—to look for gold, or to hear discourse?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, but discourse should have a limit.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The whole of life is the only limit which wise men assign to the hearing of such discourses.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Never mind about us; take heart yourself and answer the question in your own way: What sort of community of women and children is this which is to prevail among our guardians?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, my simple friend, but the answer is the reverse of easy; many more doubts arise about this than about our previous conclusions.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Fear not, for your audience will not be hard upon you; they are not sceptical or hostile.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, I replied, I suppose that I must retrace my steps. For men born and educated like our citizens, the only way of arriving at a right conclusion about the possession and use of women and children is to follow the path on which we originally started.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What I mean may be put into the form of a question: Are dogs divided into hes and shes, or do they both share equally in hunting and in keeping watch and in the other duties of dogs?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No, they share alike; the only difference between them is that the males are stronger and the females weaker.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But can you use different animals for the same purpose, unless they are bred and fed in the same way?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: You cannot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, if women are to have the same duties as men, they must have the same nurture and education?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then women must be taught music and gymnastic and also the art of war, which they must practise like the men?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is the inference, I suppose.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I should rather expect that several of our proposals, if they are carried out, being unusual, may appear ridiculous.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No doubt of it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, and the most ridiculous thing of all will be the sight of women naked in the palaestra, exercising with the men, especially when they are no longer young.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, indeed, according to present notions the proposal would be thought ridiculous.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But then, as we have determined to speak our minds, we must not fear the jests of the wits.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Not long ago, the Hellenes were of the opinion, which is still generally received among the barbarians, that the sight of a naked man was ridiculous and improper.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when experience showed that to let all things be uncovered was far better than to cover them up, the ludicrous effect vanished before the better principle which reason asserted.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First, then, let us come to an understanding about the nature of woman: Is she capable of sharing either wholly or partially in the actions of men, or not at all?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That will be much the best way.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if the male and female sex appear to differ in their fitness for any art or pursuit, we should say that such pursuit ought to be assigned to one or the other of them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But if the difference consists only in women bearing and men begetting children, this does not amount to a proof that a woman differs from a man in respect of the sort of education she should receive.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is no special faculty of administration in a state which a woman has because she is a woman, or which a man has by virtue of his sex, but the gifts of nature are alike diffused in both.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: All the pursuits of men are the pursuits of women also, but in all of them a woman is inferior to a man.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: One woman has a gift of healing, another not; one is a musician, and another has no music in her nature. And one woman has a turn for gymnastic and military exercises, and another is unwarlike.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Men and women alike possess the qualities which make a guardian; they differ only in their comparative strength or weakness.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then let the wives of our guardians strip, for their virtue will be their robe, and let them share in the toils of war and the defence of their country.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here, then, is one difficulty in our law about women, which we may say that we have now escaped; the wave has not swallowed us up alive.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, that was a mighty wave which you have escaped.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, but a greater is coming; you will not think so when you see the next.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Go on; let me see.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The law which is the sequel of this is to the following effect: that the wives of our guardians are to be common, and their children are to be common, and no parent is to know his own child, nor any child his parent.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, that is a much greater wave than the other; and the possibility as well as the utility of such a law are far more questionable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I do not think that there can be any dispute about the very great utility of having wives and children in common; the possibility is quite another matter.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I think that a good many doubts may be raised about both.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, I said, I submit to my fate. Yet grant me a little favour: let me feast my mind with the dream as day dreamers are in the habit of feasting themselves when they are walking alone.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I have no objection; proceed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You, who are their legislator, having selected the men, will now select the women and give them to them; they must be as far as possible of like natures with them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They must live in common houses and meet at common meals. None of them will have anything specially his or her own; they will be together, and will associate at gymnastic exercises.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so they will be drawn by a necessity of their natures to have intercourse with each other—necessity is not too strong a word, I think?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, necessity, not geometrical, but another sort of necessity which lovers know, and which is far more convincing.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can there be any greater evil than discord and distraction and plurality where unity ought to reign? Or any greater good than the bond of unity?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There cannot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And there is unity where there is community of pleasures and pains—where all the citizens are glad or grieved on the same occasions of joy and sorrow?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No doubt.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such differences commonly originate in a disagreement about the use of the terms 'mine' and 'not mine,' 'his' and 'not his.'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not that the best-ordered State in which the greatest number of persons apply the terms 'mine' and 'not mine' in the same way to the same thing?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It will now be time for us to return to our State and see whether this or some other form is most in accordance with these fundamental principles.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Unless philosophers are kings, or the kings and princes of this world have the spirit and power of philosophy, and political greatness and wisdom meet in one, cities will never have rest from their evils.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: No, nor the human race, as I believe—and then only will this our State have a possibility of life and behold the light of day.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Socrates, what do you mean? I think that you are aware that a word from you will rouse up a whole army of adversaries.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They will rush at you with might and main, and if you do not repel them by force of argument and get away, you will be scornfully laughed at.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You got me into the scrape.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And I was quite right; however, I will not desert you, and will defend you with what I can—goodwill and encouragement, and, perhaps, more suitable answers than another.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Until philosophers rule as kings or those who are now called kings and leading men genuinely and adequately philosophize, there is no rest from ills for the cities, nor for the human race.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: But tell me, Socrates, what is the nature of these philosophers?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those who are lovers of the vision of truth.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is also good; but I should like to know what you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: To another I might have a difficulty in explaining; but I am sure that you will admit a proposition which I am about to make.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What is the proposition?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That since beauty is the opposite of ugliness, they are two. And inasmuch as they are two, each of them is one.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And of just and unjust, good and evil, and of every other class, the same remark holds: taken singly, each of them is one; but from the various combinations of them with actions and things and with one another, they are seen in all sorts of lights and appear many.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And this is the distinction which I draw between the sight-loving, art-loving, practical class and those of whom I am speaking, and who are alone worthy of the name of philosophers.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How do you distinguish them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The lovers of sounds and sights are fond of fine tones and colours and forms and all the artificial products that are made out of them, but their mind is incapable of seeing or loving absolute beauty.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Few are they who are able to attain to the sight of absolute beauty.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And he who, having a sense of beautiful things has no sense of absolute beauty, or who, if another lead him to a knowledge of that beauty is unable to follow—of such an one I ask, Is he awake or in a dream only?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I should say that such an one was dreaming.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But take the case of the other, who recognises the existence of absolute beauty and is able to distinguish the idea from the objects which participate in the idea—is he a dreamer, or is he awake?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He is wide awake.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And may we not say that the mind of the one who knows has knowledge, and that the mind of the other, who opines only, has opinion?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those who see the absolute and eternal and immutable may be said to know, and not to have opinion only. Those who see the many beautiful, and who yet neither see absolute beauty, nor can follow any guide who points the way thither—such persons may be said to have opinion but not knowledge.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is certain.

modern.title: Book V: Women, Families & Philosopher Kings
modern.preview: Socrates: So that's the good and true city, and the good person follows the same pattern.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So that's the good and true city, and the good person follows the same pattern. If this is right, everything else is wrong.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What are the bad forms?

messages.speaker: Narrator
messages.text: Socrates was about to describe the four bad forms of government when Polemarchus, sitting nearby, started whispering to Adeimantus. He grabbed him by the shoulder and said something in his ear.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: No way, we're not letting him off the hook.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Who are you not letting off?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You. We think you're being lazy and trying to skip over a really important part of the story.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You're acting like it's obvious that when it comes to women and children, 'friends share everything.' But you need to explain what you mean.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Wasn't I right though, Adeimantus?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Maybe, but you still need to explain. What kind of sharing are you talking about?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: We've been waiting forever for you to tell us about family life in your city—how people will have kids and raise them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Count me in on that request.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Yeah, we're all agreed on this.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You have no idea what you're getting me into! What an argument you're starting!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I thought I was done, and now you want me to start over from the very beginning.

messages.speaker: Thrasymachus
messages.text: Why do you think we came here—to find gold, or to have a real conversation?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: But conversations should have limits.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A whole lifetime is the only limit for conversations like this.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Don't worry about us. Just answer the question your way: What's this whole 'shared women and children' thing among the guardians?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Look, this isn't easy to explain. Way more questions come up here than with anything we've discussed before.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Don't worry, we won't be too hard on you. We're not skeptics here.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, I'll have to backtrack. For citizens educated like ours, the only way to figure out women and children is to follow the path we started on.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me put it this way: Do we divide dogs into males and females, or do they both hunt and guard equally?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They share the work equally. The only difference is males are stronger and females are weaker.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But can you use different animals for the same job unless they're raised and fed the same way?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No, you can't.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So if women are going to do the same jobs as men, they need the same education?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So women should learn music, athletics, and warfare, just like men?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I guess that follows.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I expect some of these proposals will seem ridiculous since they're so unusual.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No doubt.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The most ridiculous thing will be seeing women exercising naked in the gym with men, especially older women.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, by today's standards that would seem pretty crazy.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But since we've decided to speak our minds, we can't worry about people making jokes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Not long ago, Greeks thought it was ridiculous and improper for men to be seen naked. Some cultures still think that way.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But once experience showed that being uncovered was better than being covered up, the ridiculous feeling went away because reason won out.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First, let's understand women's nature: Can they share in men's work fully, partially, or not at all?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's the right approach.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If men and women differ in their ability to do something, we should assign that task to one or the other.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But if the only difference is that women have babies and men father them, that doesn't prove women should be educated differently.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's no special ability for running a state that belongs to women because they're women, or to men because they're men. Natural talents are spread across both.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: All the things men do, women can do too—though on average, women are somewhat weaker.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Some women are natural healers, others aren't. Some are musical, others have no rhythm. Some are athletic and warrior-like, others aren't.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Men and women both have the qualities needed to be guardians—they just differ in strength.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So let the wives of guardians train alongside the men. Their virtue will be their clothing. Let them share in war and defending the country.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, we survived the first big wave of controversy about women. We didn't drown.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That was a big wave to get past.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, but there's an even bigger one coming.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Bring it on.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here it is: The wives of guardians should be shared in common. The children should be shared too. No parent should know their own child, and no child should know their parent.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Whoa, that's way more controversial. Both the possibility and the usefulness of that are pretty questionable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I don't think there's any question about how useful it would be. The possibility is another matter.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I think there are questions about both.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, let me at least dream about it for a minute. Like daydreamers who walk around imagining what they'd do if their wishes came true.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Go ahead.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: As the lawmaker, you'd select men and women with similar natures to be together.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They'd live in common houses, eat together, exercise together. Nothing would be individually owned.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And naturally, living together like that, they'll be drawn to each other. 'Necessity' isn't too strong a word, right?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Not geometric necessity, but the kind of necessity lovers know—which is way more powerful.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can there be anything worse than conflict and division where there should be unity? Or anything better than the bond of unity?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Nothing.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Unity happens when everyone shares the same pleasures and pains—when they're all happy or sad about the same things.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Most disagreements come from people arguing about what's 'mine' versus 'yours.'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Isn't the best state one where the most people use 'mine' and 'not mine' to refer to the same things?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Totally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's get back to our state and see if it matches these principles.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Sounds good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Unless philosophers become kings, or the people we call kings start genuinely philosophizing, cities will never be free from their problems.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Neither will humanity. Only then will our ideal state have any chance of existing.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Socrates, do you realize what you just said? You've basically declared war on everyone. They're going to come at you hard.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: If you can't defend yourself with solid arguments, you're going to get destroyed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Hey, you got me into this mess.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And I was right to! But I won't abandon you. I'll defend you however I can—with encouragement and maybe better answers than someone else could give.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Until philosophers rule as kings, or current rulers genuinely embrace philosophy, there's no end to suffering for cities or for humanity.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Okay, but tell me—what exactly is a philosopher?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those who love seeing the truth.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That sounds right, but what does it mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This might be hard to explain to most people, but I think you'll get it.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What's your point?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Beauty is the opposite of ugliness, so they're two things. And since they're two, each one is one thing.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Same with just and unjust, good and evil. Each is one thing by itself. But when they combine with actions and objects and each other, they seem to be many things.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This is how I distinguish between people who just love sights and sounds, and actual philosophers.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How do you tell them apart?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: People who love beautiful sounds and colors and art can't see or love absolute beauty itself.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Very few people can actually perceive absolute beauty.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Someone who sees beautiful things but can't see beauty itself—even if you lead them to it—is that person awake or dreaming?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I'd say they're dreaming.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But someone who recognizes absolute beauty and can tell the difference between the idea and the things that share in it—are they dreaming or awake?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Totally awake.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can we say that the one who knows has knowledge, and the one who only has opinions has... well, just opinions?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those who see the absolute, eternal, unchanging things have knowledge. Those who see many beautiful things but can't see absolute beauty—they have opinions, not knowledge.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's certain.
